After the Bodhisattva had subdued the six sense bases, he then contemplated name-and-form,
understanding its essence and characteristics, and said to name-and-form:
Due to your conditions, you are able to give rise to the great suffering of all beings. You should quickly return to your own karma.
Name-and-form said:
I do not see my own faults.
The Bodhisattva said:
How is it that you do not see your own faults?
You are deceitful, with an extremely evil essence and characteristics. Due to your conditions, you are able to give rise to the six sense faculties of all beings.
Name-and-form replied:
This is indeed so.
I am like a tree able to produce branches and leaves. Since there is me, I am able to give rise to the branches and leaves of the six sense faculties.
The Bodhisattva said:
I will now use the sharp axe of wisdom to cut down your root, and the branches and leaves of the six sense faculties will naturally fall.
NÄma-rÅ«pa said:
You cannot kill me, consciousness, the strong and powerful one who always protects me.
If this seed of consciousness were not to fall into the ground of name-and-form, how could it give rise to all suffering?
The Bodhisattva said:
It is true.
If consciousness does not dwell in the mother's womb in the kalala stage, the body of a sentient being will never grow.
If consciousness does not dwell in the kalala, this kalala will immediately disintegrate. If it disintegrates, how could there be a body of a sentient being?
For this reason, I will now burn the seed of consciousness with the fire of wisdom.
The Bodhisattva then abandoned name-and-form and observed consciousness, counting it and saying:
You are like an illusion, with a deceptive nature, like a monkey who is restless and does not stay still, and also like lightning that never stops for a moment;
Like an untamed horse that does not stay on the right path, or like a rampaging elephant that is difficult to restrain.
Consciousness said:
Who dares to insult the king of the conditioned?
The Bodhisattva said:
Who is mistaken in considering you as the king? What are your characteristics that you call yourself the king?
Consciousness said:
I take the body as the city, and the six sense bases as the gates.
As I am now truly the lord of the city, all dharmas follow me, taking me as the foremost. How can it not be so?
The Bodhisattva said:
I have honed the sword of wisdom for hundreds of thousands of eons. I will now destroy your kingly status.
Consciousness said:
How strange!
Since I have no faults, you are unjustly bearing a grudge.
The Bodhisattva said:
How can you say you are unjustly bearing a grudge? Yet you give rise to the affliction of name-and-form. Isn't that a grudge?
Consciousness said:
Name and form truly rely on each other. If there is no consciousness, there will be no name and form. If there is no name and form, there will also be no consciousness.
The Bodhisattva said:
How strange!
Name and form and consciousness are truly the greatest intimate friends in the fundamental wheel-turning of all sentient beings.
Consciousness said:
I am truly the intimate friend of name and form;
I am driven by karmic activity, placed in the midst of karma without freedom, and receive the forms of the five destinies according to good and evil.
The Bodhisattva said:
You are driven by activity, I forgive you for this fault for a while.
Although you have faults, wait for me to clarify. Now I will observe activity with the eye of wisdom, and then I will question you.
The Bodhisattva immediately left consciousness and went to where activity was.
Activity was startled and said these words:
Who are you, with such valor and lightness, wearing indestructible armor, and holding in your hand the heavy and sharp sword of enlightenment?
Foolish beings, long asleep in the night of ignorance, think of themselves as being in a place of fear and terror, yet they are able to walk alone in this careless and dark place.
The Bodhisattva said:
You have been experiencing the causes and conditions of this body for a long time. I have today thoroughly observed and realized it, and am called Siddhartha.
The practitioner was startled and said:
From where did you attain understanding?
The Bodhisattva said:
I made a firm vow in the past to make offerings and pay respects to the great Shakyamuni Buddha, to bathe and feed him, and to practice great diligence until today.
Since then, I have been adorning myself with merit and virtue without ever slacking off.
The practitioner said:
I observe that you have been adorning yourself for not very long.
The Bodhisattva said:
Do not speak like that.
I first did not attain certainty for one asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpa, but after two asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas I attained certainty in order to save sentient beings.
The practitioner said:
How strange!
You are able to love sentient beings!
The bodhisattva said:
I love sentient beings out of compassion, not out of defiled attachment that gives rise to love.
Suppose there is a herd of elephants in a great forest surrounded by fire on all sides. Who, upon seeing this calamity, would not give rise to compassion?
At that time, the largest elephant pulled a branch of a tree and beat out the fire, leading them to safety and enabling them to escape the danger of fire.
All sentient beings are surrounded by the fires of birth, old age, sickness, and death. Who, with wisdom, would not give rise to compassion and wish to enable them to escape?
The practitioner said:
You have compassion and love for sentient beings, why do you enter into equanimity?
The bodhisattva said:
I never abandon saving sentient beings!
I observe the cycle of birth and death from the edge of consciousness. All the great faults are created by you. In order to eliminate you, I come to you.
Because of you, I was born in the Heaven of the Thirty-three, where I became Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra, but my desires were insatiable;
Again, because of you, I was born in the Brahma world, sat on a lotus seat, and entered the concentration of meditation;
Up to the highest peak of existence, the place of non-perception, when my life ended, I was reborn and fell into the three evil paths.
These things were done by you.
Xing said:
It is truly as you say. The path of the king of consciousness is indeed created by me.
Wherever consciousness goes, I protect it and reach its location.
The Bodhisattva said:
I will grind the sword of wisdom with the stone of right view and cut off your limbs.
Xing said:
Please don't do it!
I cannot repay your fatigue.
The Bodhisattva said:
Why can't you repay it?
The practitioner said:
All afflictions are the fire-drill of great suffering, the mother of suffering, called ignorance.
The multitude of afflictions, impurities, and great suffering are all created by it.
You do not investigate it, but instead want to seize me. What good does that do?
The Bodhisattva said:
Where is this ignorance located?
The practitioner said:
This ignorance is surrounded by great demons and afflictions, making it difficult to subdue.
Now it resides in the evil charnel ground of delusion and afflictions.
At that time, the Bodhisattva, having learned the location of ignorance from the practitioner, gave rise to a courageous mind and went to its location, roaring:
You afflictions, demons, and ghosts!
If you defeat me, I will accept punishment and retribution.
If I am victorious over him, I will surely crush all the afflictions, evil rÄká¹£asas, and so forth, leaving none remaining!
Xing said:
As you are courageous and have firm diligence, entering the greatly fearless vajra samÄdhi, the gate of liberation will open for you. It will not be difficult to eradicate ignorance.
At that time, the Bodhisattva looked around fearlessly and captured ignorance, questioning it, saying:
Are you not dwelling in the evil charnel ground of afflictions and habitual tendencies now?
This charnel ground is a place of disgust for those who fear birth and death.
The fierce winds of inverted dust and afflictions obstruct the wisdom eye, causing it to see nothing. It is a place where various deceptions, doubts, and regrets gather like grass and straw;
The corpses of broken precepts and the dead bodies of the five desires are putrid and scattered, filling this charnel ground.

The great wind of initial and sustained thought blows on the fire of the three poisons, with fierce flames blazing;ğŸ”½Evil desires and arrogance move restlessly, with loud laughter in the midst of the skeleton;
The corpse of heedlessness and all evil observances, with impure pus and blood flowing and staining the ground.
The three realms are like a prison, with filth and stench, cutting off all wholesome roots.

Various broken vessels are scattered on the ground, cutting off the views of eternalism and annihilationism, with hair flying wildly in the wind, shamelessness and lack of conscience like tattered clothes, covering the entire cemetery.
The afflictions and bonds are like coarse and rough stones and sand, with the ninety-six kinds of wrong views like crows and owls, and various evil vultures and hawks roosting in the tombs.
Sometimes there are also beings with greed, like foxes, wolves, jackals, weasels, and mice making holes in the tombs.
There are also those who cling to precepts, like withered and fallen branches and leaves of a dead tree in the tombs.
There are also those who make decisions based on non-dharma, like a broken bed placed in the tombs.
Sometimes there are those who throw themselves into the abyss, jump into the fire, or lie on thorns, engaging in various ascetic practices like a blazing fire burning in the charnel ground.
Sometimes there are those who, relying on their own physical strength, wealth and life, become arrogant and defiled, accumulating in the charnel ground.
Sometimes there are those who are filled with the thorns of resentment, hatred, and jealousy in the charnel ground.
Sometimes there are those who, with evil thoughts and contemplation, destroy wholesome roots like flies, and the stench of impure sores and worms defiles and disgraces the corpses.

Sometimes there are enemies of the five hindrances and afflictions wandering in the charnel ground, or those who cling to the notion of self and what belongs to the self, with various sorcerers gathering in the charnel ground.
There are also various wrong views and heretical doctrines, like foxes, owls, and vultures emitting great evil sounds in the charnel ground.

There were also rÄká¹£asas holding the noose of craving, and some rÄká¹£asas holding the mace of sleep and delighting in the five desires, while in their hands they wielded a three-pronged spear. With various unwholesome and evil colors, they were frenzied, shouting loudly, and laughing boisterously without fear.
Some rÄká¹£asas shook their heads and moved their bodies, glaring and howling, leaping and jumping, roaring and slapping their thighs, sometimes whistling, singing, or dancing.

There were rÄká¹£asas of anger, rÄká¹£asas of harboring grudges, rÄká¹£asas of minor offenses with heavy retribution, rÄká¹£asas of sudden violence, rÄká¹£asas of greed and jealousy, pride, great pride, self-conceit, pride of inferiority, wrong pride, great pride, desire for what is not Dharma, desire and greed, and evil greed. Such fierce and dangerous afflictions and great rÄká¹£asas were innumerable.

The Bodhisattva arrived at the cemetery of the multitude of bonds and saw the various faults and evils of this ignorance, which covered the eye of wisdom and obstructed the source of the body, causing sentient beings to not see the Four Noble Truths, falling into evil destinies, and he spoke these words:
This ignorance is the guide on the vast road of birth and death, able to ignite the great fire of birth, old age, sickness, and death, and is the mother of afflictions, bonds, and karma.
It closes the door to nirvana, opens the various evil destinies, and is able to create a great form that pervades the three realms and is present everywhere.

With a large head of heedlessness, broad forehead of doubt and bonds, a deceptive ugly face, crooked thoughts as a pockmarked nose, the eyes of wrong views, the eyes of a child, the lightning of the four directions, the resentment of waiting for an opportunity to retaliate, the ears of a lustful one with many hairs, the deception of fraud, and deep and wide eyebrows;

Anger and rage are his sharp fangs, greed and ugliness form his upper lip, jealousy and stinginess make his lower lip hang down, and wrong livelihood, flattery, and deception make him falsely claim to be a monk.

Greed for offerings is his sharp teeth, the sixty-two views are his hair, the three kinds of craving are his long throat, the eight wrong paths are his warts and calluses on his shoulders and arms, and various evil disciplines make his claws long.

Enduring karmic bonds is his two breasts, insatiable greed is his bloated belly, sleep and regret are his deep black navel, much desire and craving are his genitals, the eighteen realms are his two thighs, wrong desires and evil desires are his two knees, the views of self and person are his feet.
Shameless elephants and dirty wet skin are his clothes, shamelessness and blue ugliness are his coarse robe, he sits on a bed of afflictions, and the demons of various bonds are his attendants.
The faults and crimes of those afflictions and evil rÄká¹£asas, even if one had a thousand tongues in the great assembly, one would still be unable to fully describe them.
Moreover, one sees the rÄká¹£asa of ignorance, with the seal of death and the wheel spinning at his side. The wise ones of the world see this and tremble in fear.
At that time, the Bodhisattva redoubled his efforts and attained the supreme samÄdhi.
He gave rise to great joy and immediately, in sequence, a pure mind was born and he attained the Immovable Ground.
His firm feet then went to where the rÄká¹£asa of ignorance was, to the level and even ground of the realm of no affliction.
He removed all anger, resentment, hateful and poisonous thoughts, and thorns and sand.
He sprinkled the dust of the eight dharmas with a rain of compassion, watering the ground and causing the roots of goodness to grow, with soft grass and the bliss of the roots of goodness.
He used the two-footed four means of unification as his feet, firmly standing out from the crowd.
With his left hand in samÄdhi, he gathered the great disarray of the sixty-two views into his hair;
With his right hand, he drew out a sharp sword.
With the minds of sentient beings who have not requested [his help], he roared like a great lion and shouted loudly, saying:
I have accumulated good dharmas in the presence of innumerable buddhas, and with the great vehicle I vow to save all. The fruits of my diligence over innumerable eons are now accomplished!

All sentient beings are burned by the great fire of birth and death. I should now extinguish it for them, subdue the thief of afflictions, cut off the flow of all conditioned activities, and rescue them from the perilous path to the supramundane!
The demon of ignorance heard this roar and, stretching out his arms in play, laughed loudly, saying:
Brahma kings, Mahesvara, Vishnu, Indra, the Four Heavenly Kings, the sun, moon, stars, all bend their knees and come before me, controlled by me.

Vashya, Vashyurula, Vashyaguru, Vashyagurula, and other innumerable sages, each with the virtue of wisdom, looked up to me as their realm, but they were all confused by me and did not know the way out.
All sentient beings, I put them all on top of the wheel of birth and death, causing them to revolve in existence and be unfree. Such things are all done by me.
What foolish child would not measure himself and grab my hair?
Yet all humans, gods, asuras, and all sentient beings are disturbed by my vigor and strength without stopping.
Who are you?
You are light, swift, and impetuous, coming to me, roaring loudly in front of me.
The arising of wholesome roots is like the sun just rising. I have never heard or seen this before.
All sentient beings are blind due to ignorance. The wisdom eye you open to see clearly, examining subtly, is like this?
Who can suddenly ferry across and lead to the other shore in the great waves of the ocean of suffering and distress of birth and death?
All foolish ordinary beings are in the wrong path. Who can suddenly guide and show them the right path?
Who can suddenly illuminate the darkness of great ignorance with the torch of wisdom?
My orders are all obeyed in the three realms, and none can disobey them.
All the sages and non-Buddhists are all happily content in my realm. Mahesvara, Brahma Heaven, and others, by my power, give rise to the thought of permanence.
Who is this fearless, supreme person with great courage who is not afraid of me and dares to grab my hair?
Excellent, excellent!

You are now definitely born from the Buddha's lineage. The power of right contemplation, incomparable merit, and great compassion are your essence. You must be a bodhisattva who compassionately saves sentient beings.
His virtue is revered and majestic like Mount Sumeru, and except for this superior person, no one in the entire world dares to raise a hand to grab my hair.
The Bodhisattva replied:
What you have said is truly correct.

I have cultivated various wholesome practices since ancient times, all for the sake of saving and delivering all sentient beings. As you have said, the one called a Bodhisattva is none other than myself!
Ignorance said:
Great-minded sentient being!
Your wisdom is unshakable, and you are determined to save others, regarding enemies and friends equally as if they were of one taste, like a blazing fire burning fresh leaves.
The wisdom fire of your present mind burns me in the same way.
You are now firm and upright, and I will follow your teachings and never dare to disobey.
The Bodhisattva said:
I will send you away quickly with the seal of suffering, emptiness, impermanence, and no-self, without any hesitation!

After the Bodhisattva had spoken this seal, the evil army of the afflictions and ignorance fled and ran into the ninety-six kinds of wrong teachings, and their dwelling place became the ignorant mind.

At that time, the Bodhisattva extensively gathered various provisions for the path, and without a teacher, he alone awakened and extinguished ignorance. Therefore, the multitude should cultivate the six pÄramitÄs and extensively gather good dharmas.
Able to skillfully contemplate what is said by the sages, later attaining great joy and understanding the profound meaning.

In the ravine, an evil dragon became angry, and a great cloud and thunder rained down large hail,
And lightning struck down in the empty village.
The evil ghosts in the gathering are extremely angry and rain down great fires all over the country.
The beings of the world are tormented by the fire and all flee together into the great river.
They devour the blood and vital energy of all beings, and those who enter the river reach their palace,
Suffering extreme pain and entering the overturned [hell], they then enter the stone mountain with a single hole.
The beings emerge from the hole and enter the great ocean, the salty and bitter seawater dissolving their bodies,
Crying out and wailing, calling out to their parents, 'Which deity can save us?'
At that time, on an island in the ocean there was a divine horse king who always ate naturally ripened rice, fat and strong.
Hearing the voices of the suffering beings, the horse king cried out,
Who now wishes to cross to the other shore and reach JambudvÄ«pa?
All the people who fell into the water raised their right hands and said,
Save me, save me!
The king of horses then shook his body, and the eighty-four thousand hairs bristled and grew long. Those who grabbed the hairs were all freed from suffering.
For what meaning is such a parable cited?

The blind people are likened to the ignorance of all sentient beings. The bees are likened to karmic activity. The donkey is likened to consciousness. The donkey falling into the abyss is likened to consciousness falling into name-and-form. The empty village is likened to the six sense faculties. The hail and lightning are likened to the impermanence and harm in the six sense faculties. The evil ghost is likened to contact. The rain and fire are likened to the various feelings. Falling into the river is likened to craving. The rÄká¹£asa in the water that eats people's vital energy is likened to the four kinds of grasping. Entering the covered place is likened to the three existences. The great stone hole is likened to birth. The great ocean is likened to old age, death, worry, sorrow, and various sufferings.

The king of divine horses is a metaphor for the Buddha, with the body of good merit, right intention, and firm reality, with the hair of eighty-four thousand kinds of goodness of right mindfulness and concentration, and with a compassionate mind for all sentient beings.
All sentient beings suffer greatly, being born by birth, aging by aging, and dying by death.
However, sentient beings do not know the expedient means to seek the essential path of escape. The Buddhas lead and guide sentient beings in this to enable them to leave suffering.
